newsitem.title: FINLAND: NOKIA SEES DOUBLE-DIGIT MOBILE PHONE MARGINS.
newsitem.headline: NOKIA SEES DOUBLE-DIGIT MOBILE PHONE MARGINS.

text.p: Finnish telecommunications group Nokia Oy sees double-digit margins in its mobile phone business within reach next year, Nokia spokesman Seppo Harkonen said on Thursday.
He was referring to CEO Jorma Ollila's comments to analysts in a telephone conference in the afternoon.
"(Ollila) said double-digit margins on mobile phones are possible in 1997, and that we are close to that now," Harkonen told Reuters.
In 1995, Nokia Mobile Phones operating profit was 10.9 percent of net sales.
Harkonen said Ollila had told analysts that Nokia's telecommunications infrastructure business aimed to achieve 30 percent net sales growth for the year.
"What he said is that we have set to ourselves a fairly aggressive target of reaching the 30 percent (growth) level in the infrastructure business in Nokia Telecommunications," he said.
In January-September, year-on-year sales growth was 28 percent, dragged down from the 30 percent in January-June by a 26 percent figure in the third quarter.
According to Harkonen, Ollila had said Nokia was "fairly confident" it would be "very close" to that target.

Sales growth in Nokia's telecommunications arm was slightly lagging behind target partly due to customers' timtables for deliveries but that the order inflow was strong, Harkonen quoted Ollila as saying.
